Anyhow, so we get there on a Saturday morning, and the place is packed. No biggie, most good breakfast spots usually have a wait on a weekend morning. I think we waited about 30 mins, which wasn't bad. We're seated, we order, everything is just peachy. Then things started to go sour.

It had been about 40 minutes since we were seated and we still hadn't received our food. Other diners who were seated after us had received their food and were finishing up. Our waitress hadn't stopped by our table in a long time. I had started to wonder if maybe our ticket was lost (ordinarily I wouldn't think anything of it, but the fact that people seated after us had gotten their food made me think something might have been wrong). Anyway, so the next time we see our waitress walk by, we flag her down and ask her if she knew when our food would be out. We asked politely. We weren't snarky, we weren't mean, we didn't roll our eyes or snap our fingers. It was a simple question, one that I think many would probably ask. And the waitress replied, "Are you really hungry or just really impatient?" No hint of a smile on her face. No twinkle in her eyes. It was clear that she wasn't joking (not that it would have been funny anyway). 

Hmm. Are we really hungry or really impatient? Well, neither...we just wanted to make sure our ticket hadn't gotten lost. We sat in stunned silence, unsure of how we should respond to such a flat-out rude remark. The waitress left, and finally brought our food out about 10 minutes later (and then we never saw her again except for when she dropped off the check). By that point, our appetites were pretty much gone, and we just wanted to leave. So we scarfed down our food and got the heck out of dodge.

I dunno. Maybe the waitress was having a bad day. Maybe she gets asked that question a lot (by actual impatient people) and is sick of hearing it. But we were very polite to her and didn't deserve to be treated like that. I don't care how good your food is (and for the record, the food was okay, but certainly not mind blowing for the all the hype), if you have lousy customer service, I can't support you. And it's a shame, because I really, really wanted to like this place (it looks like such a cute mom and pop place). With so many other great breakfast spots in the Burgh, I'd rather go somewhere that cares about giving their customers a good (or at least not a blatantly bad) experience.

We stopped by for brunch on a Friday at Dor-Stop Restaurant and were not disappointed!  They have brunches here every day, it seems, even on weekdays.  
Even on a weekday at 11am, expect to find this place quite crowded!  We waited about 15 minutes for our table.

Pittsburgh was our last pit stop (no pun intended) on our roadtrip to the Midwest in mid-October and we decided to eat at the best restaurant we could find for lunch.

I ordered the steak n cheese hoagie and loved it.  It came with thin slices of steak, swiss cheese, sautéed onions, green peppers, diced tomatoes, and shredded lettuce.  It was served with fries.  I really appreciated how much steak was in my sandwich - they sure were generous!  

They have a number of breakfast-type foods on the menu as well, if you're so inclined.  The French toast looked quite appetizing, and something I would definitely get if I visited again in the future.

Service was really friendly and homey at this restaurant too.

The only issue is the parking situation - it's pretty much a "find-a-spot-if-you're-lucky" street parking type place.  But if you are driving through Pittsburgh and you do find parking in the vicinity, definitely check Dor-Stop out!

I have to be honest, I have heard that this place has great potato pancakes but I couldn't care less. Why? Because I eat the same thing every single time I eat there. I have no time to be bothered by some silly pancake when there is serious business, in the form of eggs benedict, that needs taken care of. The eggs benedict at The Dor-Stop is just the way I like it. I feel like so many breakfast spots serve benedicts of all sorts that are usually quite small, have very little hollandaise and are served with a salad. Maybe I am the odd one out in all of this but I cringe when I see a salad served with breakfast foods. I go out to breakfast to eat unhealthy, artery clogging deliciousness. If I wanted to concern myself with veggies I would stay at home and save my money and eat at home. Anyways, their eggs benedict consists of the diner's ham off the bone, two eggs, mancini's bread and a pool of delicious hollandaise. There is no stinginess when it comes to this meal. Everything is heavy handed. In addition to the huge eggs benedict, there is a beautiful mountain of potatoes that comes with it. Everything about this dish is how it should be. Total perfection.b

Writing the review for this place is pretty cool! I've wanted to go here for a long time.  I'm from New York and visit Pittsburgh frequently because my gf current is here! I've seen this place featured on Diners Drive In's and Dives and love all the food places I've been to in Pitt! I've tried a majority of the Pittsburgh staples for breakfast but the Dor Stop by far is the best breakfast I've had in the Pitt! The Orders were Vickie's Jumbot and their famous pancakes (apple walnut) the Jumbot features a mix of eggs veggies home-fries ham topped with Italian toast! Was very good ! The pancakes were amazing filled with hot apples and crushed walnuts them to were amazing... The only thing I was upset about was that they wouldn't allow substitutions and were gonna try and charge me a ridiculous amount to sub turkey for ham at like $5.99, didn't think that was fair, other then that the service was great, people were friendly and it was very enjoyable to go here!
Delicious food, friendly and timely service, reasonable prices, big portions. This is THE PLACE to eat breakfast! The pancakes were great but the Guy's Jumbot was phenomenal!

If you ever need an explanation of what a bottomless cup of coffee truly signifies, check out the Dor-Stop.

In addition to that lesson, the you will experience the following:
-Hotcakes so good you don't need to add syrup (mine were oatmeal raisin, like eating the amazing hybrid of a cookie and pancake)
-Potato pancakes so good that you'll wish you had multiple orders
-Slabs of ham. So good.

Add in the great service, ease to find parking, and decent prices and this place is truly a gem. Don't let the wait scare you unless you have a large group - people flow out of there pretty quickly, and for 2 people on a Sunday we only had to wait 10 minutes (and they gave us free samples while we waited). And it is definitely worth the wait.

Jammed on a Sunday morning but they were able to get our party of 10 in with just a 15 minute wait.   And Pumpkin pancakes awesome!!!  Not seasonal- all year around.   Nice place to bring a crowd or a cozy group.

We stopped here with on a rainy Saturday morning with great anticipation given the reviews and I agree with Lawrence W. and Krissy D. that I dont really get the hype.  The place is small and loud so there was a wait which was fine, but the wait staff was not particularly friendly and very distracted.  They were much more interested in turning tables. We had a variety of food and it was all just OK and none of it great.  Some of the portions were huge to their credit, but very average.  Even though its more "corporate", Pamela's was a much better diner experience than Dor-Stop.  I doubt I would wait again.

A breakfast favorite. Always good. Try the banana chocolate chip pancakes! Beware that it is small and you often sit elbow to elbow with folks at the next table. It's also very busy on the weekends. Totally worth it.

I stopped by for lunch and had the steak salad.  It was pretty yummy but the steak had too much fat on it. The reason why I am giving it only 4 stars is because my steak was not done the way I requested and our waitress had zero personality.  I recommend going here for breakfast and not for lunch.

The Dor-Stop is amazing. I recommend it to everyone who wants a good breakfast. They have the best pancakes I have ever had. You usually don't even need syrup. The service is good -- the servers are attentive and professional, but there's a mom-and-pop feel about it too. I travel from an hour away to visit about once a month or so. It's that worth it. Reasonably priced.

The only drawback is they don't have real maple syrup. (Only Cracker Barrel seems to in the US, but that's just the Canadian in me.)  There are usually pretty long lines waiting for tables; but miraculously the wait is so short -- even on holidays.

Other than that: favorite. breakfast. restaurant.

The Dor-Stop is a must visit while I am in Pittsburgh. I visited here again on my recent trip.  The food is still fantastic.  The omelette special is great and the potato pancakes are some of the best I have ever had.  It gets really busy on the weekends, so I suggest getting there earlier.
Food, awesome. Servers, friendly and attentive. Always a wait on the weekends, so make sure you are ready for that. However, the turn around is quite fast, so the wait is never very long.

Still craving their pancakes. It's been weeks. 

The price is decent for a diner, maybe a little pricier, but I'm pretty sure I'd name my first born after this place. The service is quick and friendly and you get seated pretty fast so no worries! 

I tried their sandwiches and they were pretty killer, but the pancakes. The pancakes. I dream about the doughy, melt to the top of your mouth, sugary meal.  It is food deserving of the gods. 

Then again, I'm partial to breakfast.

best breakfast in the burg. i got the raspberry french toast which lives up to its expectations, but could have used more egg. i also got the egg benedict which was really good and a nice portion. he chocolate milk is decent. the fresh squeezed lemonade was very good. 

negatives- 25 min wait (although it was sunday morning) and small tables/crowded

I saw this restaurant on Diners Drive-ins and Dives and knew that when I was in Pittsburgh I just had to check it out. Let me tell you I was not disappointed it was exactly what I expected. I had the pumpkin spiced hot cakes which were truly one of a kind. Hands-down some of the best hot cakes I've ever had. If you're close to Pittsburgh this place is a must !!!!

Without a doubt, this is my favorite place for heavy, hard-core, carb-loaded, mouthwatering pancakes. The pumpkin and banana walnut bring a smile to my face just thinking about them. If somehow pancakes aren't your thing, the jumbot and eggs Benedict are amazing. I don't know what they do to their ham, but it's worth just ordering it as a side. I'm too fixated on the breakfast items to branch out into their other menu items but I'm sure they are also amazing.

Best breakfast in Pittsburgh. Every time I come here I'm never failed.  On my most recent adventure I took my Mom and Step dad, who were in for a visit.  There was a special on sausage biscuits with gravy. OH. MY. GOD.   It was so delicious, it was ALMOST was good as my grandma's.  I savored every bite, and my only issue was that there wasn't more.  :(
As always the restaurant was packed and loud. I love that about the Dor-Stop b/c it's so Pittsburgh.  Did I mention how much I love this place?!?!

Boston has Cheers.  Dormont has the Dor-Stop.  

When I moved to Dormont a few years ago, I was told about this amazing breakfast place that was featured on the Food Networks show, "Diners Drive-Ins, & Dives".  I now know why this place is a Pittsburgh staple - Delicious food, Friendly service, and a Cozy atmosphere.

If you go on the weekend, you'll typically see a line.  Don't let it turn you away!  It usually moves quick and its worth the wait.  It's a small diner atmosphere, so i wouldn't recommend it for parties larger than 4.  Once you get inside, I assure you that you'll be hooked, too.

I've tried several things on their menu - The breakfast burrito - HUGE and delicious with eggs, potatoes, sausage... The pancakes - dense and hearty!  The French toast - who would have thought cornflakes applied to this would make it even yummier?  And my FAVORITE - Vicki's Jumpot - Everything you could ever want in a breakfast!  Eggs, potatoes, ham, cheese, peppers, onions... and though it comes with Italian toast, I swap it for some of the best marble rye in the area.  Incredibly filling, big portions but little prices and always tasty.

Yes, it's got to the point where the hostess knows my name when we enter - "Ashley, party of 2?"  That's me!  I look forward to any Sunday I get to dine at the Dor-Stop.  Sometimes you've gotta go where everybody knows your name...

Pancakes, pancakes, pancakes.  Everybody told me I HAD to try and their pancakes.
Well, the short stack they served me were lousy pancakes.

WOW. When you read "best pancakes ever", believe it. 

My boyfriend and I were on our way from Milwaukee, WI to Easton, PA and figured we should find some good food along the way, and The Dor-Stop fit the bill - we'd be arriving near Pittsburgh at just the right time for breakfast. 

This place was bustling - we got there at about 8:30am on a Saturday, but we only had to wait a few minutes. 

Our waitress was sweet and courteous and she told us about the popular items on the menu because we'd told her it was our first time there. 

He and I both got the Eggs Combo - two eggs, choice of meat (bacon, sausage or ham off the bone). He got banana pancakes and bacon and I got pumpkin pancakes with the ham. 

The ham was wonderful - albeit a little salty (but all ham tastes salty to me), but by the time I finished my perfect over-medium eggs and one of my pancakes I was pretty full, so I wasn't able to finish the ham. That didn't stop me from sneaking a couple of bites of my boyfriend's banana pancakes though! 

If I ever find myself driving east again, I will be sure to take the detour out to the Dor-Stop. I will be dreaming about the pumpkin pancakes until I can manage to somehow make something half as good. 

Absolutely amazing! Best. Pancakes. Ever.

I just met up with a few friends here today. First timer!!! The meal was classic eggs toast bacon and hash browns... And it was fantastic! Diner coffee can always be hit or miss, but this was on point. The service was quite friendly and always there for a refill of a drink or to see if we needed anything at all. I enjoyed the cute small town diner atmosphere. It's definitely cozy, so if you're not a fan of being seated near others I would recommend somewhere else. But the coziness gives it a lot of wholesome character, and I will most definitely eat here again!

I'd say something bad about the restaurant, if there was something bad to say. We are big fans of DDD; which led us to seek out the Dor-Stop. We were good with being told it would take 25/30 minutes to get a table for four. Ten minutes later we were being seated. The restaurant offers a large menu; everyone should be able to find something to their liking. Everyone ordered something different at our table. It came quickly, was hot and most importantly, tasty. I had the Crab Benedict. Real Crab folks! The Hollandaise sauce was prepared nicely and the fried potatoes were excellent. My wife had the stuffed strawberry French toast. She said it was great. Coffee refills were timely and the overall cost was pretty reasonable. If I lived in the area, I'd be a regular.

I have been to The Dor-Stop numerous times and never been disappointed. They are known for their pancakes as featured on The Food Network's "Diners, Drive-ins and Dives." 

I always get pancakes when I go and my favorites are banana walnut and pumpkin. These pancakes are thick and fluffy and so filling! I always end up taking at least one home. My husband has also tried their french toast which he highly recommends. 

They get busy during the peak breakfast/brunch hours so a wait is sometimes necessary but they move fast with service without rushing you and you get out quick.  It has your basic diner feel. It is clean and service has always been warm and friendly. Prices are very reasonable in my opinion as my husband and I both eat for under $20. 

I love the Dor-stop and highly recommend it to others!

I assume lots of folks have seen this place featured on Food Network's Diners, Drive-ins, Dives. This place is exactly as it is on the show, really tasty breakfast foods all made from scratch. Great family atmosphere with friendly staff.

I had the apple cinnamon hotcakes and the cheese steak hoagie sandwich. 

The hotcakes were just awesome. They came as a stack of three hotcakes with a lump of butter and a squeeze bottle of syrup.

The hoagie was just average, kind of small with lettuce tomato, green pepper seasoned with salad dressing and mayo. Kind of weird.

Coffee wasn't very tasty either, or rather seemed to be on the mild side.

Note their hours are 6a - 3p. Metered street parking and a metered public lot down the block.
Great food! They were able to accommodate a large group on a very busy Saturday morning with hardly any wait!

Oh my gosh! Best breakfast I've ever had. I had the raspberry stuffed pancakes and bacon. The bacon was perfectly crisp and tasty - just a bit too salty. The French toast was absolutely incredible. They must dip the bread in some sort of crispy breading because it's delightfully crisp. There was raspberry sauce and raspberry drizzle and if it wouldn't have freaked out the other customers and my husband, I would have licked the plate. I HIGHLY recommend. It's small so you might have a short wait but it's worth it.

What an awesome spot for brunch. Though we don't live too far away the traffic was horrendous and all we could think about was some yummy food to shovel into our mouths. Even though the place was packed we were luckily seated right away and presented with menu eery person wants to see on a Saturday morning. we all ordered what we wanted and didn't have to wait too long! Best part is, everything is made from scratch and you can def tell. 

We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves at a decent price and we will for sure be back.

Tasty! I hear it gets busy on weekends, but we went on a Monday and got seated and served very quickly. I very rarely can't finish my meal, but it was so much food. Omelet was great, I'll have to go back and try the pancakes. Coffee was perfect diner coffee.

After a lazy Saturday morning visiting my in-laws, we decided to stop here for brunch before catching a movie at the cinema up the road. First, good luck finding parking in the area! My finance and I parked about 5 minutes away which wasn't a huge deal, but not being from the area it was a massive headache. But thats the worst we dealt with.

The restaurant itself is pretty small but cozy. We had a party of 6 and they sat us right away. (It was around 1pm on a Saturday.) I ordered the vegetarian omelette and home fries and I can say it was one of the best omelettes I've had! Huge portions and everything tasted great! Fiancé opted for the meatloaf sandwich and he said it was also delicious. Father-in-law got their signature stuffed french toast which came with a generous serving of bacon and toast.

Loved the hometown feel of the place and it was a nice stop before we headed to the movie. You defiantly won't leave hungry here!
Don't go for healthy, go for tasty comfort food. Great pancakes. Expect a long wait on weekends!

All I can say "bombass" pancakes!  Minus a star for the stares! I forget sometimes where I am. Traditional old school greasy breakfast. Everything homemade!  The cook & our waitress was cool. I guess they started chatting with us b/c the regulars couldn't stop glaring.  I guess it' worth the 2 to 4 hr on the weekends. Luckily, I came in on a weekday. Maybe that's why all the stares?  I don't care. Just give me my pancakes, sausages & hash browns  that Guy raves about. Everyone who works there was really good & portions were fit for steel workers.

This place has a great reputation.  It probably makes it more popular than it otherwise should be.  I really tried to sample what they are known for as I do many places I visit for the first time.  Turns out they know what they are doing.  

This is your quintessential diner.  Friendly, sassy staff that make you feel like you are at home.   Wait for a table (because there will be a wait) or try to snag a seat at the counter either way you are getting big portions served to you quickly.  

I got the jumbot (basically an egg scramble with various meats and veg) with the hot sausage and a side of German potato pancakes.   The hot sausage made what would have been a relatively pedestrian dish quite good. I probably could have ate just a bowl of that. The second best thing I tried there was the potato pancake.  Really nice flavor and they give you the option of sour cream or applesauce as a condiment.  I tried both and the sour cream was the clear winner there.  I tried my wife's chocolate chip banana pancake and it was also quite good.  

Nice diner doing a good job serving the community.  The food is probably somewhere between 3.5 and 4 stars but because of the intangibles it gets rounded up.

This place takes the (pan!)cake for cozy morning breakfast.

Growing up in the South Hills, this is where you tried to go every Saturday morning.  Note I definitely said TRIED, as if you arrive after 11, you better be very patient.  This place is small and people love to relax and stay a while.  However, this is one of the few spots I will leave the house for before noon on the weekend.

You might have seen the spot on the Food Network.  If not, look it up.  The owner and her daughter are crazy endearing.  The focus here, of course, is on the pancakes.  This is the only place I know of that serves pumpkin pancakes year round, and it is for a reason.  These are dense and sweet, enough that even I don't syrup them.  A little whipped butter in a paper souffle cup and a dash of salt (hey, don't knock it 'til you try it), I can clear three or so in a few minutes.

They also have staple breakfast items, along with the jumbot. At least one of the guys in my party always goes for the ham on the bone/jumbot.  If you can fit this thing in your body, go for it.  The only other unique item to try would be the stuffed french toast.  Personally, between syrupy fruit filling (compote is too kind a word for this ice cream topping inside) and then topped with more fruit syrup, it tastes more like a heavy dessert for me, but I know those who swear by this as their weekend treat.

If you find yourself on the other side of the Liberty Tubes on an early morning, you need to go get pumpkin pancakes.  You can even call ahead for it to be ready for take out and avoid the mess of hungry Dormont-ers along the Potomac sidewalk, but then you'd miss making new friends with your slightly brash waitress and the infamous specials on the tiny chalkboard.  Either way, depending on your timing, this diner will hit the very top on your breakfast list.

WOW! I really don't know what else to say. Hands down, the best breakfast I've ever had from a restaurant.

We were looking for a good breakfast place on Saturday and I found this one on Yelp. The reviews were great and the pictures looked so good that we had to give it a try. Thank you yelpers for helping me find this gem!

I had the Jumbot "Guy style". It was so good I HAD to eat the whole thing. Which was no easy feat considering how big of a plate it was. A heaping plate of everything but the kitchen sink. Eggs, hash browns, pepper jack cheese, onions, peppers, hot sausage, and more! On top if that, my boyfriend and I had to try a specialty pancake as well. Luckily you can get just one. We had the apple cinnamon cake and it was absolutely heavenly. Crispy on the outside with a doughy, yet done, center. It melted in your mouth!

He had the regular breakfast with the potato pancakes which The Dor-stop is apparently known for. I didn't get a chance to try them since he demolished it in mere minutes. I'm assuming they were delicious. 

It was reasonably priced and very cute. We were fortunate enough to get a table right away but I've heard there can be a pretty long wait. Sometimes out the door which makes perfect sense after tasting this delicious food.

Dor-Stop Diner is a gem!  Make sure you come hungry.  The apple oatmeal pancakes were delicious and perfectly prepared.  My friend had the raspberry French toast.  Both were excellent choices.  The waitress was super nice and prices were very reasonable.  Great spot and a fun new find!  I'll definitely be back.

Great neighborhood diner! The food is always consistently good, especially breakfast. Personally I recommend their pancakes, soo so delicious! It gets packed on the weekends, but the street is cute with some interesting shops so NBD.

I just love this place.  My grandma lives just a few minutes away, so it is has recently become one of our stops when we come visit her. 

The environment of the place is perfect: friendly, happy, and serving great food.  I even found the coffee here delicious.  

I got the special for the day, which was the Irish Jumbot.  My grandma explained to me this morning that jumbot, when referring to food, mean just a plate full of different kinds of things.  That is exactly what it was.  The reason this was an "Irish" jumbot was because it had corned beef in it.  Oh my it was delicious.

In the past my mother has ordered the flavored french toast with the blueberries.  I still remember it being one of the most different and delicious breakfast plates I have ever had.  

I will defiantly be back to the Dor-Stop soon.  It is honestly one of the best breakfast places I have been to in the area.

Probably my favorite breakfast spot in the city.  Yes, Pamela's hot cakes are amazing, but this place has the best all-around breakfast for sure.
Best thing to do is get there right when they open.  Don't be surprised if there isn't already a crowd standing outside.  If you do have to wait for a table, be patient, it's totally worth it.  Try the hotcakes.  My favorite is the pumpkin flavor they have end of summer/fall.  They're SO fluffy and delicious.

DorStop is my favorite breakfast spot but on this visit I was extremely disappointed.  I stopped in on a whim alone and sat at the counter.  While I was eating my delicious breakfast a dishwasher stood in front of me and spit  in the garbage can on the other side of the counter literally a foot away from me.  I immediately wanted to throw up.  I did not finish my meal and got up and paid and left.  They were too busy too mention something and they never asked how everything was or I would have said something.  I am not sure if I will go back which is really a shame.  I love that place.

I stopped in here after seeing the place on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. I had a late breakfast with my boss, as we were both in town from Miami to do some research for the travel section in the magazine I edit.
Unfortunately, this was the first DDD meal that didn't leave me wanting more. The marquee dish on the show was the Jumbot. I had it and it didn't do very much for me. That said, it wasn't bad either.
On the bright side, my boss said that Dor-Stop's was one of the best eggs benedicts he'd ever had. He's very critical of restaurants, so I take that praise pretty seriously.
Service was as friendly and informal as yo

Delicious food. Friendly and prompt service. Only complaint is there is no pork alternative (I.e. Turkey bacon, turkey sausage, etc) the staff makes sure you feel comfortable and always keeps your coffee cup full! Definitely would like to return!

What more can be said about this place? You need to try the hot cakes!!

At first I wasn't sure three of these would be enough. Sure enough, when they came out, I thought "okay this is a decent amount"... and then I proceeded to take my first bite.

These are the fluffiest, most incredibly good and filling hot cakes that I've ever had! I don't know how they do it! I made it through 2 1/2 of them before I hung my head in defeat. But it didn't matter, because I was in my happy place. These cakes are absolute heaven, and if you haven't tried them yet, you are missing out!

I never thought I could get emotional about food, but this is one of those times. I recall my mom once craving crabs from a crab shack in Ft Lauderdale for over 10 years after having them once. I feel like Dor-Stop pancakes will be the equivalent for me. My God, will I miss this place and those hot cakes.
Good, standard diner breakfast fare.  The potato pancakes tasted a little sweet, which was odd.  The pecan French toast was spot-on delicious.

1 star service, 3-4 star food.  And the only reason service gets a 1 instead of zero is because a 2nd waitress covered for the rude inattentive first one.  Look back through these reviews and you'll see other people with the same complaint.  Wife and I stopped at 7AM on a Saturday.  There were 2 waitresses and the place was about 2/3 empty.  Our waitress was uncomfortably unfriendly to us, but to people she recognized that came in she was pleasant and chatty.  We heard the specials when she was at the table next to ours but she didn't tell us.  After the first coffee refill she never came back and the other waitress stopped twice at our table instead.  When she did stop at our table and we'd say thanks for the refill or for bringing our breakfast, she completely ignored us, no you're welcome, nothing.  The food is decent but not good enough to ever come back there if we have to take a chance on getting stuck with that waitress again.

This place is the BOMB I had the best omelette ever the Jumbot  it came with potato style hash browns and some bomb toast  I also got to share a philly omelette and some banana pancakes. Everything was 5 star even the service.

This is what a diner should be.  Yummy, fresh(ish) food with staple american bites like burgers and meatloaf sandwiches.  Cramped, with experienced servers that leave the check on the table with the food.

My soup was the meal's highlight- obviously made from scratch in the kitchen.  Reuben burger- pretty good.  Side of fries- okay.  came from the freezer, but were served hot.

I would dine again.  if i am ever awake during their hours of operation.

Had the steak n' eggs when we went there.  I prefer the same thing from the diner around the corner.  Apparently this place is known for their pancakes.  Maybe I'll try that next time. A consisteny line of yinzers around the block can't be wrong.

Another DDD spot to cross off my list. First one in the East Coast!

I was intrigued with their pumpkin pancakes and raspberry stuffed french toast when I watched the segment on DDD. Finally had the opportunity when I visited by brother for his graduation at Carnegie Mellon. The wait time is killer, so be sure to bring something to entertain yourself for the time being. I think we waited for half an hour, but we weren't terribly hungry, so it was fine. Finally sat down and looked at the menu deciding what to order. Both the pumpkin pancakes and raspberry french toast looked so good, but I didn't want to be a pig and eat both of them (well, I could if I wanted to). My mother suggested that we can order both items and split it from there. Brilliant! Get to taste the both worlds. :)

Pumpkin pancakes were delish! A bit on the dense side, yet still fluffy. Spices were so fragrant, like it was Thanksgiving! Not terribly sweet, but at the perfect amount where you don't need the syrup. Huge servings; your serotonin levels will rise. :) The raspberry stuffed french toast would probably have to be my favorite. The crusty/crunchy exterior of the french toast slices stole the stage. The whole dish was sweet enough that syrup was also not necessary.

Their peach cobbler french toast special looked tempting, but sadly they ran out right when we were seated. Sad. :(

Why we pay $9 for an omelette with a couple ingredients, boring home fries, and 2 slices of "off the shelf" basic bread, I don't know, but I just did. How these inexpensive breakfast foods have risen to the price of a decent meal I don't know. Save your money and get the same breakfast for less than $5 at the local Eat n Park chain. Or go somewhere where they have some creative breakfast menu items like Pamela's.

The best part about the Dor Stop was that they didn't make me pay for the half cook unacceptable potato pancakes.
We did not accept a free meal but we had the potato pancakes removed after the waitress agreed they looked disgusting and were inedible. 

I love DDD so this was at the top of my list.

Parking is difficult and hard to come by. It's Potomac Avenue. 
On my way in someone said "don't order the pancakes they were terrible and half cooked" when I asked how everything was inside. Yikes - he wasn't kidding. 
My pancakes were undercooked and not good. 

We haven't returned. It was definitely a disappointment.

After an appointment with my new doctor in Brookline, Dad decided to take me out to brunch. 

"Hey, what's that place that Guy went to?"

"Which guy?"

"Guy Tieri. That goofy kid on that food channel."

"Guy Fieri, you mean. What? Dor-Stop?"

"Yeah, yeah, that place."

"Ok, we can go again." 

"Oh I know that sound. You already been there. Well, tough. I'm buyin'"

Dad's getting up there in digits. How guilty would I feel if he met his maker without having gone to The Dor-Stop?

Dad went with a safe sausage-n-eggs-n-home fries breakfast that he enjoyed the bejeezus out of. I became demented and ordered something from the specials on the chalkboard: The Chili Cheeseburger Bowl. 

I'm thinking D-S's recent rise to fame may have had an influence on the creation of this psychotronic horror film in a bowl. Bizarre, gaudy, and obscenely edible, a hamburger patty is placed atop some biscuits, anointed with cheddar that is melted into a crisp dome of sorts, doused with chili, and garnished with diced onions in the raw. The heavy biscuits took in the red, meaty, yet mild juices of the chuck-n-bean laden chili, which was complimented by the hardened cheddar and fresh, sweet onions. Savory, crunchy, doughy, beefy chords were all struck by a meal that if it were a song, would have been recorded by Slayer...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwllpSP97G8

And if darkness hadn't been already enthroned triumphant, for dessert I had a fiendishly fudgy wedge of a chocolate cake so debauchedly bulky, it would make angels choke...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FMsPat2hmrA

Only a glass of milk blessed by a cleric could wash it down. 

Diner Demons lurk in Dormont...

As do Darren and his Daffy Dad. 

"I think you take this ^&%$ too seriously," he sez.

Yes... Dorstop was on the Food Network but I believe that the show has brought too much business to the local breakfast/lunch restaurant. Most of the time the servers are cranky and rushing so they forget items or customer needs and the food isn't as good as it used to be. Either they need to expand their staff and restaurant or many others will see what I have.

Have been to the Dor-Stop a couple of times recently.  Able to get a table almost immediately.  One time I had the pancakes.  The pancakes are really good and actually more than I could eat; probably one of the better items on the menu.  Another time I had a eggs benedict special that was pretty good but the Hollandaise sauce is not that good just OK, probably not real fresh or comes out of a can. 
Both times are service was pretty good.  Our waitress was on top of it and friendly.

Definitely a must-try diner in Pittsburgh, and a great place to take out-of-town guests for a unique breakfast.  
My plate of choice has got to be the Apple Cinnamon Pancakes.  If you are going for the first time, make sure somebody in your group orders pancakes.  They are a must try.  The raspberry french toast is delicious and very filling too.  The omelets are good as well.

A nice surprise as I'm not a diner person. We stopped by on recommendation of a friend after a hockey game. The pumpkin pancakes were delicious, as were the west coast eggs Benedict. Beware, though - the eggs Benedict are not served in typical fashion. It is the size of the plate and served with potatoes. The toppings were placed on top of several slices of (good) Italian bread. 

Some reviewers mention the servers. Yes - a bit short, however, expected with as busy as they are. Our waitress was short, but extremely nice, attentive and we had great customer service. I think they just want to turn tables since there are so many people waiting in such a small space. 

Expect a wait - put your name on the list & expect a minimum wait of 30 minutes. We took our hockey team and they were very accommodating in separating and seating us at several tables when they were available.

We experienced great service!! The apple cinnamon and pumpkin pancakes were amazing!! Very dense and filling with perfect flavor! The home fries are more like giant chunks of potatoes smashed a little bit, not crispy. The eggs were great but the bacon sucked (definitely recommend sausage instead). Definitely would return to have more pancakes.

Came here on a Sunday morning. There was already a bunch of people waiting outside. Wait was about ten mins which wasn't bad. 

The servers were efficient and ran like a well oiled machine.  

We ordered the special pumpkin French toast and the guy's version jumbot. The French toast was delicious. It was covered in the pumpkin spread which I worried would be too sweet but it was just right. It came with a few strips of crispy bacon. 

The guys jumbot was a melting pot of delicious ingredients including eggs,  potatoes,  jalapeños, hot Italian sausage and cheese. At first,  we thought it would be spicy on the account of the sausage and jalapeño but it wasn't,  instead it brought the dish to life. The Italian toast really brought this powerhouse of flavors home. Becareful the portion is large and can fill you up quickly.  

Will definitely return for another delicious breakfast one of these mornings.

I didn't realize this place was featured on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives. The place itself is small and has that diner vibe. Despite being small and busy we were seated right away. Our waitress was great! She was around many times to refill our coffees and was very attentive. I tried the Guy's mix (I honestly forget the name). It was delicious. If you're in the area you should check it out.

A little further than most brunch places, but hoped it would be worth it. It was hard to decide what to order here because people have raved about half the items on their menu. Decided to get the stuffed raspberry French toast (which looked really good in photos so I knew I had to get it), sausage patties (you get one meat option with the French toast), and German potato pancakes. To be honest, I didn't think the food was amazing. I did enjoy the raspberry French toast, but like most people have already mentioned, it wasn't exactly stuffed. Sausage patties are a staple brunch meat for me, but these tasted microwaved and like they've been sitting out for a while. The potato pancakes I was pretty excited for, but they didn't taste like the potato pancakes I've had at German restaurants, so it wasn't what I thought it'd be. The French toast alone I would give 4 stars out of 5, but the sides I got bring my taste rating for Dor-Stop down. Although I would consider coming back, I'd definitely order different sides.

Taste | 3
Atmosphere | 3
Presentation | 3.5
Service | 3.5
OVERALL | 3.5

Best breakfast around. 

The pancakes are indescribably delicious. I mean, every time I eat them I'm in disbelief by how amazing they are. The banana pancakes are one of my favorite foods in this world. The bacon is also very good and crispy. 

They have good lunch options, too. They made a good burger and the Rueben is very good. 

Friendly staff and welcoming atmosphere. 

They get very busy on the weekends, so expect to wait for a table. Trust me though, it's well worth it!

Folks this is very overrated.. they had Guy's Diners Drivein and Dives there only because Guy's parents knew owner. This is very avg food at best. Its nothing special.I wont go back.. Very small and uncomfortable. They have a large sign in window to play on Guy's visit a number of years ago. Dont fall for it.

I went to this location on a Saturday morning at about 10 a.m. It was just me and my boyfriend. The wait was about 10 to 20 minutes at the most. The seating is kind of cramped however I get it because it's a small dinner. I was anxious to go because it had been featured on the Food Network. I can say that I was not disappointed with my omelette nor was I disappointed with my boyfriend's raisin bread french toast lol. He also got Circle sausage partties. He said the eggs were superb! I ordered the South of the Border omelet. Being a Southern girl I wanted to make sure that the Omelette would stand up to its name. The omelette was large in size and came with some homemade potatoes. The omelette was tasty it was wrapped with sausage and different vegetables which was good with cheese and salsa on top. Yummy to say the least however I would have preferred some sour cream with it as well. (I was so hungry i didn't bother to ask) I gave this place four stars for the good, quick, friendly, tasty, service I received. It was IHOP prices with the home feel.

I was kinda disappointed. I came here for brunch with my boyfriend on his birthday. We got seated right away, but waited 10 minutes for anyone to come up to us. I understand that they were busy, but 2 people after us got seated and served before we did. We finally got served and the waitress wasn't all that nice. No apology for not being waited on for 10 minutes. Needless to say....their food was amazing. I had guys version of the jumbot and I can't stop thinking about it. If I had a little better service then would totally be a 5 star, but service is something that makes people come back. Hopefully it was just a. Very busy and off day for them, because everything else was awesome!

Came on a Saturday morning and there was a 10 minute wait. Been here several times and always get the pancakes. This time ordered the pumpkin pancakes which was perfect for fall. The pancakes are moist, dense, and filling. I didn't even need syrup! The bacon was also cooked perfectly and a nice change from the sweetness of the pancakes. My friend ordered the veggie and cheese omelette and was pleased. Always a great place for breakfast.
This was a wonderful place to stop in for brunch. Delicious Exquisite food, and fantastic service.  I would stop in here again any time when I'm in town.

This was my second time at the Dor-Stop and it was just as great as the first. First time, we got there around 10am on a weekend day, and there was a wait outside. Second time, we got smarter and still went on the weekend, but earlier- 8am. Yes, rolling out of bed early on the weekend is a pain, but well worth it. 

The first time I ordered the Eggs Benedict and from my memory it was a must-try, I would order again. Today, I got the Banana Walnut Hotcakes and they were perfect! The bananas were fresh and visible, and there were just enough chopped walnuts so it wasn't underwhelming or overwhelming. 

The service is great. Our waitress was very attentive, and always around for drink refills, but not the annoying "always stopping by". She also made sure to grab the box that I almost forgot as we were leaving because the portions are huge. Overall, outstanding traditional diner in the South Hills.

I dream about this place and how yummy it is, you should expect a wait on the weekends, because I'm not the only one who feels that way.   Right now I'm on a potato pancake kick, I seriously can't walk out of there without having them.  They are also quite famous for their regular pancakes white are deliciously dense, I don't think we've ever had anyone at our table finish their pancakes, but they heat up well the next day to prolong the decadence!

Wow!!  My wife and I had breakfast at the Dor-Stop this morning and it was outstanding!!  We had about a 20 minute wait to get in but it was worth it.  The service was fast and the food was great.  We will surely return......

I've heard of this place quite a few times, but haven't found myself in the area to try it out. I was pleased to find they were open on the 4th of July (relax, people. We tip well.) so we stopped in.

There was a LONG line waiting to get in to the small, diner style setting. I went in to put our name on the list and there were two breakfast bar seats available! Score!

Even though they were out of this world busy, the staff was friendly and chatted us up when they would pour some more coffee for us. 

I thought I wanted breakfast (I mean, I did, but the menu has so many good choices!) but I went with the Rachel Reuben. It was great! Also served with two of the best potato pancakes I've ever had. Applesauce AND sour cream, please. :)

The hub had a philly cheese steak (and half of my Rachel) with fries. There were no leftovers to be had.

All in all we are glad we stopped in and will definitely be back!

First of all, this place is packed for a reason, but if you are alone or with a friend stools at the bar are first come, first serve.  We got in quickly that way, and enjoyed a couple of American breakfasts (eggs, potatoes, hot rope aka hot sausage, toast).  

The service was prompt and friendly and the food delicious.  Also cheap as hell.  We always try to stop here when in Pittsburgh.

My second trip here.  The first was on a weekend.  Never again.  Too crowded and I had to squeeeeeeeeeeeze onto a counter stool between two strangers.

Today I went on a Friday morning  Was lovely and got a booth to myself.

Both time the food and service were 5 stars.  Really good breakfast staples.  I had eggs, bacon and home fries today.  Also a side order of potato pancakes, because why stop with just one starchy dish?  

These pancakes are not your bubby's potato pancakes, though they do come with apple sauce or sour cream (or both if you ask nicely). These are, I guess, German style.  They have some chopped up vegetable (broccoli?).  They also have the dreaded (for me) ingredient of garlic.  I cannot eat garlic.  It makes me feel illllllllllllllllllll.  Plus i taste it for daaaaaaaaays.  So, one bite in I realized I had ordered something I couldn't eat.  But I couldn't send it back -- it was perfectly prepared, fresh, etc.  So I decided to say nothing.  

But the waitress walked by and noticed I wasn't eating the potato pancakes and asked me what was wrong.  When I explained the garlic thing, she immediately offered to take them off the bill.  Without my asking.  Instead I welcomed a second order of bacon (moo moo, that's me).  Next time I will remember to try the ham from the bone because that looked terrific!
Upbeat atmosphere and very good breakfast! The home fries and banana oatmeal pancakes were sooo delicious!

I went in intending to get the much ballyhooed Rasberry Pancakes, but as I browsed the menu the server, Laura, highly recommended the Oatmeal Banana Pancakes. So, I changed my order. Although I did this immediately, and apologized sincerely, this really ticked Laura off, though she said it was okay. I also asked for a box (saving her an extra trip), since I only eat 1 pancake.

The big pancakes arrived so piping hot, I had to let them cool almost 5 minutes. No box, though. They tasted very good, pretty balanced flavors. They were "heavy",  hearty, I guess.  Laura insisted I try it without syrup first. Okay. It was so tasty, I ate almost the whole pancake before using syrup. I took the other two home, but had to ask for a box. Again.

The coffee was typical diner coffee. I hunted Laura down, previously just standing at the counter, who was wiping the last table in the back, asking for a refill.
Two minutes later, she brought coffee, took my plate and all my silverware. She didn't bring more cream (I was out). I didn't see her on the floor (hardly at all during my visit), and told the two servers chatting behind the counter, that I didn't have cream, or a spoon, and needed to go, so I didn't even drink my second cup. They became huffy, and said I should've asked for more cream and a spoon (I was in the ladies room). They didn't offer me a cup to go, either. So, I left, but with a slightly bad taste, because of the service.

They have one of the best breakfasts in Pittsburgh. I have never had anything bad here. Great meat products, just don't get the sausage patties. They are not of high quality, but everything else is. French Toast is excellent. Pancakes are good, but are really sweet like a donut. You have to be in the mood for them. Like I said they are very sweet. Only negative of this place is the restaurant is small and crammed, it is always packed, and there is always a wait.

Warning: you will not be seated until your entire party is there and parking sucks!  This place is jamming busy and very noisy.  Beware if you have a hangover.  The banana pancakes are good and rest of what was ordered smelled yummy, too.  This is an experience, but perhaps not a repeat for me.

I have had this place on my bucket list for some time now. Today my girlfriend and I decided to go for brunch. We had a very difficult time parking but managed to secure a spot on the street. After "feeding the meter" we went to the diner and learned that today and tomorrow they had free street parking due to July 4th holiday.

We laughed it off and were seated fairly promptly. The place is small and very crowded. Food is all homemade from scratch. My girlfriend opted for breakfast so she settled for a veggie omelet with toast and I chose a turkey Rachel. The sandwich came on marble bread and was filled with sauerkraut an cheese. It also came with potato pancakes. Portion sizes were generous and the food was very good.

They are noted for their pancakes which we will try on another visit. We got our meals rather quickly and our waitress was very attentive to our needs. There is an $8.00 minimum charge for credit cards and there is a sign telling you that you must tell them when you order whether or not to split your check.

The tables are topped with various advertisers and they have interesting things to observe while you wait for your meal.

My suggestion would be to come during off hours or non-holiday especially if you want to have a nice breakfast or lunch. They are only open until 3 in the afternoon. We had a wonderful time!

This is the second review of The Dor- Stop, I gave it another star this time.

Canadian Friend of Joe (CFoJ) was getting ready to catch the 4:45 flight to Philly, and wanted to share one more meal before leaving the Burgh. He was hungry for breakfast, after all it was only noon and he was still in bed. So he calls me and says meet in Dormont for some serious diner food.

He's already at a table when I walk in, sitting there eating a huge cinnamon roll, split in half, grilled and looking soooo delicious. So he points to the wall and says "Guy from Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives was here". Spitting pieces of Cinnamon roll at me in his excitement, who knew Canada got the food network?

I ordered the oatmeal pancakes, knowing full well there are eggs in the batter (somethings are just worth having as a vegan) but at least I was smart enough to have the butter on the side so I could discard it later.

He ordered the raspberry french toast, over hard eggs (Canadian for broken yokes) and bacon, a large OJ, coffee, and the cinnamon bun he was noshing when i entered. The man can eat, and he's so thin, I really hate him and his metabolism.

My oatmeal cakes were HUGE, and three to an order, I got the first one down without any problem, they were moist, chewy, flavorful with real oatmeal and cinnamon, and the syrup was almost not needed as they have a natural sweetness to them.

He devoured his french toast, eggs, bacon, saying it was one of the best breakfasts places he's ever been to.

It's a shame we take restaurants for granted, here's a guy from Vancouver, over 3000 miles away wishing the Dor-Stop was in his home town.

As avid DDD devotees when we visit any town, we had to try one in Pittsburgh and Dor-Stop was (kind of) on our way. Parking is tough around here so my husband dropped me off so I could put our names in.

We were worried about the wait but only ended up waiting about 15 minutes and got 2 seats at the bar. We ordered the signature raspberry stuffed French toast and Guy's version of the Italian Jumbot. 

The French toast was super yummy and the Jumbot was also tasty. However, though still good, the Jumbot was not as impressive as we had hoped for an signature dish. It was kind of an omelette with potatoes and a bunch of random ingredients. Also just to note, the French toast is not "stuffed" but rather the raspberry sauce is drizzled generously on top. 

Our bill was under $20 so it was a quality meal for a very very low price. No complaints on our end, Dor-Stop is well worth a visit if you're ever in the Pittsburgh area!

Fellow Yelper Lori has this...thing...for Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives. It's not about Guy Fieri, it's about the mom & pop spots, where people do their food up with a lot of love and plenty of grease (elbow and otherwise). The Dor-Stop has been featured on DDD, and so, we needed to eat here.

Like many places in the Pittsburgh area, I've been lost in this neighborhood before, but never noticed this cute little place. NOTE: it's small, it's crowded, come with only your best friends, be prepared to make friends while you wait for a table to open up. If you're lucky, the front counter folks will bring out pancake samples while you're waiting - they're a cross between Deluca's and Pamela's - kind of crispy on the outside but fluffy on the inside? I dunno.

ANYWAY. Service, efficient and friendly. Menu - all the good stuff, with potato pancakes and other little bits, along with the DDD featured items. I got the Guy's Way, which was a nice mix of savory breakfasty things. Tasty without the need for hot sauce.

We were in and out pretty quick, but didn't feel rushed. Classic diner - will be back if'n I'm over this way again.

Went here on a Saturday morning at about 10am and only had to wait about 10min for a table (party of 2). Service was quick and polite, food was delicious, and prices reasonable. I got the chocolate chip banana pancakes and my husband got the west coast eggs Benedict. It was definitely worth the trip to Dormont from the north hills. Recommend getting here before 10 because the wait seemed to be quite a bit longer when we left a little before 11.

Loved the pirogies but it ended there. Three cheese Mac n cheese was average. My breakfast was warm by the time it got to the table and cold within five minutes on a cold day because the restaurant was so cold. Wouldn't go back

We finally made our way to Dor-Stop after always hearing people raving about how it's the best in the city. We went around 10:30 on Sunday and had to wait about 45 minutes for a table for four to open. The atmosphere is exactly what you would want and expect from a diner, right down to the greasy food and cramped dining area. My in laws got oatmeal walnut pancakes, which they liked, and a side of home fries. They have been here before and that's what they always get. Why mess with what works?
 
I ordered the farmers omelet, which to be honest didn't really have much flavor. There are so many ingredients in it that I couldn't single anything out. The bright side is that they were quick with the coffee refills, and more importantly they poached my wife's eggs perfectly. Which isn't easy to do. 

The meal was pretty cheap for four people, and the atmosphere was cool, so we will probably give it another shot. I would just stick to a more simple omelet.

I went to the Dor-Stop last weekend for breakfast.  My friend explained to me that this was a long time staple to the neighborhood, it was a diner, but it was GOOD!  I am usually skeptical of diner food, but when he told me that it had been featured on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives I figured it must be pretty good!

I don't usually order sweets for breakfast, but I decided to switch it up and get the Raspberry Stuffed French Toast.  Whoa - holy sweet, rich, and delish!  The bread had an odd texture for french toast, it almost tasted deep fried.  The raspberry compote was really good but I was only able to eat half of my dish, so we switched plates half way through the meal.  He had the Guy's Jumbot, which was a large scrambler with spicy Italian sausage, jalapeno, onions, peppers, egg and cheese.  It had a great kick to it without being over powering.  Even though my french toast was really good, I was kind of regretting not ordering a savory dish.  We also had a short stake of pancakes to share because he told me that the Dor-Stop was known for their hot cakes (secret recipe).  I am not a huge pancake person, but I could tell that there was definitely something a little bit different about these.  They were flavorful and had a hint of a spice I can't put my finger on.

The service was quick and everyone was friendly.  The servers were constantly walking around re-filling water and coffee.  When we were leaving there was a huge crowd near the door waiting to be seated.  I suggest going early if you don't want to wait for a table.

They have great bacon!!! I ordered a simple meal just the bacon and pancakes. Their pancakes are good but very very dense. Lol. They are not your typical pancakes. I don't even think I could eat a whole one before I was full. 

I cannot remember any issues with them. Which was nice. Food was good,  service was good as well.

It will be a while before I step foot in here again, if at all.  Ordered the All-American Breakfast, burger well done and eggs over medium.  The burger was rare and not cooked.  Ridiculously pink in the middle of burger.  The eggs were snotty, not even cooked enough for sunny side up eggs, let alone over medium.  How freaking hard is it to cook a burger?  Or eggs?  I'm sorry I'm one of those people that cannot eat ground meat not completely cooked.  I would rather have it burnt than not cooked at all.  Turned my stomach and couldn't take another bite.  2 stars for the lyonnaise potatoes or it was gonna be one star.  And in this place, it's basically you bought it, you eat it!  Or don't eat it! But don't expect it to be rectified.

Cute little place in dormont. Unique and delicious breakfast items. Delicious egg dishes and their pancakes are also made perfectly. This little gem might be my new favorite breakfast spot in the Burg!

Always busy but worth the wait. It was even featured a Diners, Dives and Drives. I get the Guy's version for breakfast. Chorizo sausage, eggs, potatoes,  onions, peppers, tomatoes, cheese and jalapenos. My wife loves their raspberry stuffed french toast or banana chocolate chip pancakes.

I wish this place was closer to where I live now. This was my go to for breakfast when I lived in Brookline. 

Totally worth the wait.

Absolutely love this place. The hot cakes are my favorite. Chocolate chip or apple cinnamon, can't go wrong with either. Always very good service when ordering for pickup as well. Looking forward to the next breakfast I can grab here already.

You know how JImmy Buffet has Cheeseburger in Paradise? Mine is more like Pancake in Paradise and this place is it! 

While Pamela's serves up the amazing thin crepe-like pancakes, The Dor-Stop serves up the fluffy equivalent. The list of different combos goes on and on. And if you're with a really good friend, you can order two different ones and split them! Genius!

I split the banana chocolate chip pancakes and the pumpkin pancakes. While the pumpkin was incredible, I think I slightly more enjoyed the banana chocolate chip just because the combo is such a winning one! But come fall, I may be all over the pumpkin ones again. Although, I'd probably be cheating myself because I have to work my way down the list of them all!

The only thing that would pull me away would be the french toast. It almost seems cruel I have to choose between the two! And it's so dirt cheap too! I think for three people it was around $25 bucks. With coffee and some sides! 

I think there's some other stuff on the menu, but who knows if I'll ever even experience them... how can I with those pancakes!

Great food and great service (a waitress not even ours double-checked my coffee-refilling needs).

For the money, the portion sizes are large enough to either _really_ fill ya up or provide leftovers.

Nice atmosphere, good location, and such and such. Just do it ... .  :P

Sister was driving through the area and heard pretty good things about this place, so we decided to try it out. We had to order take out since my sister needed to get back on the road. She got the Farmer's Omelette and I got the Meat Lover's Omelette. They were both pretty tasty; the home fries were delicious; and the toast was good. However, it wasn't anything spectacular or out of the ordinary. It was good diner food though; I liked it.

An experience worth having when visiting the area. The pancakes are above and beyond what you'd expect. The service is less than stellar, slow and orders incomplete. In spite of that, it is worth a visit. An extra kudos for a clean restroom.

For all the hype of this South Hills breakfast spot...meh. Just stay in the city for breakfast/brunch. World famous hot cakes? If you're into dense + chewy...perhaps. There are plenty of omelettes and other savory selections, but they just aren't that special except for the jumbot and the melt in your mouth Italian toast. The coffee is average and the service is anything but friendly -- not a good impression for a first timer.

Went there for breakfast - get there early, because it was packed. It had a real mom and pop diner feel, with local advertisements all over the top of the table. I got their (apparently) well known Jumbot - a dish with everything thrown in - eggs, potatoes, peppers, onions. I got the Guy version, which had hot peppers and hot sauce. Honestly, if not for the peppers, I really don't think that I would have cared for it too much - it would have been quite bland, and I still used a lot of ketchup on it. Having said that, it was still filling and tasted pretty good. My friend had their french toast - filled with raspberries. We both liked that very much - light, not too sweet, and tasty.

J and I came here for breakfast. Potomac Ave was under construction, however people were still flocking to this spot which said something to us. Our wait time was 20 minutes, so we decided to take a walk as it was nice outside. The diner was a nice place with a diverse clientele, from couples to families, to college students, which was important for us. All of the waitresses were great and worked well together. I ordered the Farmer's omelette consisting of turkey, mushrooms, spinach, tomato, and cheddar cheese. It also came with onions, but I don't like them. With my omelette, I ordered a bagel and potatoes. J ordered 3 pancakes with a side of breakfast ham and coffee. Everything we are was so delicious! The food was tasty and not too heavy. Everything was around $25, which made J happy. Definitely a place we will be returning to.

Let's be honest, there are some core diner foods out there that rarely vary from location to location.  For example, scrambled eggs.  I have yet to see someone toss out something like, "Wow, the eggs were simply divine - fluffy, yellow and...and....fluffy and yellow."  Generally speaking, your homemade scrambled eggs probably taste pretty similar to your diner eggs.  Now, let's talk pancakes.  Pancakes are a different beast.  You see, you could add buttermilk, regular milk, water, ice cream, eggs, various flours, and a plethora of additives to create your perfect pancake.  At The Dor-Stop, I received my generics and quite honestly, the pancakes scared me a little.  Why?  Well, because when I put my butter on them, the outer crust made a sound.  Yes, I said crust....on a pancake.  Not pizza....p-a-n-c-a-k-e.  I figured if nothing else, I now had a frisbee to take on my way down to Orlando.  So, I began to slice in to my crusty cake and I noticed a squishiness as I penetrated the outer shell.  How perplexing, I thought!  This felt like a job for Sherlock Holmes!  Since he's not real, I moved on.  I took a bite and I must tell you, these pancakes were flipping awesome.  Yes, that was a flapjack reference.  The crunchy on the outside coupled with the chewy middle were a serious but welcomed surprise.  I had no idea pancakes could have this dichotomy!  I polished off my stack and finished my generics with delight.  If these pancakes did not floor me, I would say this diner is still a slight step above many others of its kind, but these pancakes do give it a leg up.  As far as the environment, it is a diner.  So, it looks and feels like a diner.  The neighborhood is cool, though.  When I went there was some construction but everyone on the streets were friendly and for some reason, "Come and play...everything's A-OK.." kept going through my head as I walked down the alleyway.  Now, was there a little green monster peering at me from the lid of a garbage can....?  I guess you'll need to check it out yourself.

The Dor-Stop was the best diner food I have had in Pittsburgh in quite some time. The atmosphere and staff are exceptional. I ordered the eggs Benedict and they used real thick-cut delicious ham. I would recommend that Pittsburgh natives and visitors give this place a shot.

If I could give this less than 1 star, I would. My fiance were visiting Pittsburgh and tried Dor-Stop because of the great reviews....we were UNIMPRESSED.  It was super crowded, there was nothing special about the menu ( except some slop combination eggs, potatoes and cheese that I can make at home), and the pancakes were a little undercooked for my taste.  I asked the waitress to take the pancakes off the bill, and she told me that they have to charge me for 1 pancake since I let my fiance taste it. SMH. I gave them another chance and ordered a sandwich to-go so that I had a snack for our drive home, and I threw it out because it was DISGUSTING. Don't bother going.

When I saw that this place was featured on Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives, I was immediately sold!

The decor felt like grandma's house. Little knickknacks everywhere and the signs are hilarious! The staff constantly bussed tables at an impressive speed. We sat at the window seat, awesome for people watching! 

Food was excellent! Certainly one of the best brunches I've ever had. I ordered a veggie omelette and my boyfriend got an Italian jumbot. My omelette was packed with delicious veggies and his jumbot had these perfect crispy little homefries. 

Dor-Stop only gets 4 versus 5 stars due to lackluster service. Our waitress did her job properly. However, we did not get her name, no smile, no friendliness that you would expect at such a cozy establishment. 

I left feeling empty in my heart, but not my stomach!

We went for breakfast after seeing this place on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives.  SO amazing, I had the stuffed raspberry French toast.  Everything tasted so fresh and delicious , worth the wait if you go!  My kids tried the Hot Cakes, so much better than pancakes!

This place is ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC. Went to Pittsburgh for the weekend, ended up going twice in 2 days for breakfast. The staff are very nice and welcoming, and were very helpful in choosing what to get. The pumpkin pancakes are the best I've ever had. Ever. They are an absolute MUST. The banana chocolate chips pancakes were amazing. I ordered the jumbot with no meat and it was amazing. Their coffee is great too. What more could I want in a breakfast place? Will definitely come back if I'm in Pittsburgh again, I just wish they had one in NJ. Highly recommended!!!

Pumpkin Pancakes are to die for. Actually all their pancakes are to die for. This is a place featured on the Food Network's show "Dinners Drive-in and Dives" that did not disappoint. 

A local place run by a local family of friendly people. Affordable prices, delicious pancakes makes for a gem in the downtown area of Dormont, PA.
Perfect diner food!  We really enjoyed our brunch here over the weekend.  Definitely will be going back soon!

I went to the Dor-Stop for a quick bite for lunch. This is the first time I have felt compelled to write a review. I ordered the eggs Benedict. It was the most delicious eggs Benedict I have ever had. It was a new take on a classic. The staff was so nice and welcoming. I will absolutely be returning!

Shortly after moving to Dormont, while browsing the shops on Potomac, I came across the this gem of a diner. It was a Sunday after church and the line was wrapped around the block; as a diner enthusiast this was a fantastic sign. 

A few days later I brought a friend there for lunch the feta burger I had was amazing. The next time I went ,with my sister and nephew,  I got the burger again and an order of their famous pancakes. The flavor options were long, but I choose banana walnut. These where hands down the best pancakes I have ever consumed. 

The atmosphere is wholesome. The waitstaff is not friendly but accommodating. Honestly they don't have time to be overly friendly they are too busy. However they do a fine job serving you. 

All in all this place is an A-. The only downside for me was not having The cast from cheers welcome me by name. But the food is remarkable.

So with all the hype I was expecting fireworks.  Maybe I am tainted.  When you come from California where the food is very fresh, you are sometimes disappointed, this was one of those times.

My son watches, triple d, was so excited to be here, but at best was ok.  No fireworks.

I had the veggie burrito, my one son the egg burrito, and other son had the egg breakfast.  I ordered a side of bacon also.

My waitress brought out three scoops of sour cream, in little white contains, soggy to say the least.

My burrito, good; kids food was ok, eggs terrible bacon, Terrible.  I love bacon love it, this bacon was cheap tasting and tasted like the girdle.  Gross...

Sorry Dor-stop.  

If your every in Folsom Cali try Mary's gold miner cafe.  The bomb!
